Mostly minor things, but I'd like to see a patch series that shows where this changeset is going with this.  I suspect we're attempting to make this a non-global, but it's not obvious to me how this is accomplishing that, and I don't see any decedent patchsets.

Thanks for your response.

The reason behind moving busMap from FruDevice.cpp which is declared as static and also wanted to use the busMap in FruUtils.cpp. Because, planning to move some common functions from FruDevice.cpp to FruUtils.cpp for fru and ipmb-fru daemons usage. 

Because of this only, I moved busMap variable to Utility struct.

This is patch for moving getFRUInfo to FruUtils.cpp. 
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/50921
Why create a struct with a single item in it?  Is there another patchset that makes this make more sense?
Also, "Utility" is almost definitely the wrong name for this type.

Ack. I will update the struct name with FruUtil. 

Could you please suggest the struct name if it is not OK ?

We can add more variables in the struct if we wanted to use in multiple files.

This is the one of the patch for moving common functions to FruUtils.cpp
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/50921


Will submit another series of patchset of moving functions to FruUtils.cpp to make use of fru deamon and ipmb-fru deamon.

After that planning to push ipmb-fru related patches.
What would this structure be used for or to contain? FruUtil still is not very descriptive.

This structure used to containing global variables used between fru and ipmb-fru deamons.  

I will update Struct name as FruUtilGlobalVar.

I have two questions:
1. If it is FruUtil global var, why not go to FruUtil.hpp?
2. What are the other data members or methods this Global struct will include? Code written as is does not need the struct.

1. Yes. we can move to FruUtil.hpp as well. 

The reason I keep this struct in the Utils.hpp is, if any Global or Common Variable is used for this entire repo, we can use that struct, that's why I named it as Utility. 

Later, Thought it is mostly used in fru-deamon and ipmb-fru deamon applications. We renamed it as FruUtilGlobalVar.

2. Initially, I declared BusMap variable as Global variable since it is needed for both fru and ipmb-fru applications. Based on Ed suggestion, not to use Global variable and Create a Utility Class for that. 

Please refer this patch review comments.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/47246


Background :

We have a multi host system and we wanted to read the host FRU details which is ipmb based connection from BMC. So, created the below patch for adding support to read/write the host FRU details from the ipmb interface.

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/39593 

Implemented a separate daemon "ipmb-fru"  to handle this FRU read/write.
This "ipmb-fru" daemon uses the existing functions "getFRUInfo", "updateFRUProperty", "addFruObjectToDbus" of FruDevice.cpp. 

So, moving these functions to FruUtils.cpp to make use of the both fru and ipmb-fru daemons. Also, moved some variables to common file to used by these two deamons. Refactored the existing FruDevice.cpp file.
Also, splitting these patches into small patches into small patches for easy review.

Please find the below patches for these implementations.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/49418 
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/49205
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/49076
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/39592 
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/47246 
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/50894 
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/50921 
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51555.

so, we can add the variables "powerIsOn", "unknownBusObjectCount" to this Struct "FruUtilGlobalVar".  I have moved these variables to local variables by passing parameters to the functions. These variables also used by both fru and ipmb-fru deamons. 

Could you please suggest, if we can move the variables "powerIsOn", "unknownBusObjectCount" or any other common variable used by both fru an ipmb-fru applications. to  this "FruUtilGlobalVar" Struct.
 
or, Please suggest, If we can move this "busMap" variable to Global variable and can remove this Struct.

Thanks for the detailed background info and the list for the related series of patches. Please use the same Topic so they can be easily identified. 

Some of them already merged. For the rest of them, is there a dependency and should be reviewed in certain order?

As for the variable, they don't seem to be logically related. I don't see the advantage of putting them into a generic named struct. I am ok with just leave them separated. Maybe add a namespace to avoid name collision, and add a little clarity.

This patch is the parent patch. 
Following patches are the dependent and follow up patches.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/50921 
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/entity-manager/+/51555.

Earlier busMap Variable was declared separately as global variable only. If MAINTAINERS/Reviewers are ok to keep this is as a global variable, I am fine with that. 

So, Please confirm to keep it as the separate global variable.

Thanks, focus on this review first then.

From a reviewer perspective:
I don't understand the question on global variable. I don't know how defining a struct affect the scope of the variable. What is the difference between: 

inline BusMap busMap;  vs  inline Utility utility; ?

Also inline does not change that the variable busMap or utility) is still global, right?

Ack. Initially, I declared busMap as Global variable only and not with Class/Struct. After got the review comments as abstract it to utility class, Then I created a Struct to move that busMap into it.  

I will revert the Struct changes and declare it as earlier.
Doesn't an 'inline' definition in a header file make for potential duplicate definitions of different variables for each compilation unit?

No. The inline variable is allowed to be defined in multiple translation units. It also follows the one definition rule. If this is defined more than one time, the compiler merges them all into a single object in final program.

👍.  I hadn't read the C++17 addition of inline variables until now.  Looks like you are correct.  One of the requirements is that all compilation units will end up having the "same address" for the inline variable, so we are all good here.  Thanks.

Looks like master branch itself has this CI issue. 
Tested with master branch with my local CI setup.
